Identify What Got You Here

Similar to a vehicle, your body requires proper fuel and maintenance in order to function at its best. If you want to get the most out of your training, focusing on your nutrition is the right place to start. 

Nutrition can be broken down into two main categories. Micronutrients and macronutrients. Micronutrients are vitamins and minerals–like calcium and zinc for example. Macronutrients are carbohydrates, fats, and proteins. This program will dive into more detail on how these nutrients play an important role in optimizing your sports performance and recovery.
<p>Every body and every sport has unique:
Every body and every sport has unique demands. A long distance runner will have a very different training program when compared to a wrestler. One requires more endurance energy reserves where the other requires more explosive power and strength. A personalized nutrition plan will help each athlete consume energy and nutrients required for their specific sport, while promoting proper recovery.

<h2><b>Build a Strong Foundation</b></h2:
Build a Strong Foundation

In this activity, we’ll zoom in on each macronutrient and look at how it works, why it’s important, and where you can find it on your plate or in your pantry. 

Carbs = Fuel

Fad diets have historically given carbohydrates a bad rap. But really, carbs are a main player in providing energy to your body, particularly your brain, nerves, and muscles. 

The body breaks down most food we eat into sugar molecules called glucose, which is used as energy. If the body doesn’t use it right away, glucose is stored in the body as glycogen in the liver and muscles. During physical activity, muscle glycogen is converted to glucose and used as fuel. As glycogen stores are used up–usually during lengthy workouts around 90 minutes or longer–you start to feel tired and the body starts to break down fat and lean muscle for energy. Who wants to lose their hard earned muscle mass to be used as fuel? Not us. 

Eating enough carbohydrates can improve performance and prevent injury while maintaining muscle mass, stamina, quick thinking–all leading to improved performance and injury prevention. Quick-acting simple carbs are ideal for exercise because they quickly replenish blood sugar. Outside of exercise, more complex carbs–like brown rice and whole grain bread–are the best choice. 

Carb-rich foods include:
<p>Whole grains (brown rice, whole grain: Whole grains (brown rice, whole grain bread, whole wheat pasta)
<h4><b>Protein = Build + Repair</b></h4>:
Protein = Build + Repair

Proteins help support many functions in our bodies like muscle building, muscle repair, metabolism, and immune function. In longer workouts, when muscle glycogen stores are depleted, protein can be used as a source of energy. 

Though it’s tempting to think more = better, your body can only use so much protein at a time–about 20-25grams–so it’s important to divide up your daily protein requirements across your meals or snacks. High quality, protein-rich foods include:
<h4><b>Fat = Energy + Transport + So muc:
Fat = Energy + Transport + So much more

Fat is used as a main energy source during longer, low-intensity workouts such as walking. Using fat as an energy source helps preserve glycogen stores and delays muscle fatigue during endurance training. Fat tissue helps maintain body temperature, supports a healthy immune system, and absorbs and transports nutrients from your diet. 

There are two main types of fats in our diet: Saturated and unsaturated. Saturated fats are associated with increased cardiovascular risk and inflammation. They should be consumed less often. Saturated fats to eat less of:
<p><b>Unsaturated</b> fats help reduce o: Unsaturated fats help reduce oxidative stress and inflammation, and promote a healthy heart and brain. Healthy fats to reach for instead of saturated fats:
<p>Fatty fish and shellfish (salmon, her: Fatty fish and shellfish (salmon, herring, trout, oysters, shrimp, scallops)

<h2><b>Let’s talk about calories.</b></h:
Let’s talk about calories.

Calories are the amount of energy released when food is broken down. The more calories a food has, the more energy it can provide your body. Eating and drinking too many calories can lead to body fat storage. Eating and drinking too few calories can lead to a decreased metabolism and breakdown of lean muscle mass as energy–no thanks! 

Though they’re not 100% perfect, there are ways to estimate your daily calorie needs. These equations give you a good idea of your needs but shouldn’t be used as the end-all be-all for your nutrition choices.
<p><b>Step 1: </b>Calculate your resting: Step 1: Calculate your resting metabolic rate (RMR). This is the energy your body needs to function while at rest. It can be affected by many factors like age, gender, hormones, sleep, or medical conditions.
<p><b>Step 2: </b>Multiply your RMR by a: Step 2: Multiply your RMR by an activity factor. This accounts for the calories you burn while exercising.
<p>Don’t stress if math isn’t your forte:
Don’t stress if math isn’t your forte. We’ll walk through an example to show you how to get your numbers!

Step 1: Calculate your RMR* (weight in kilograms, and height in centimeters):
<p>Men: (10 x weight) + (6.25 x height): Men: (10 x weight) + (6.25 x height) - (4.92 x age) + 5
<p>Women: (10 x weight) + (6.25 x height: Women: (10 x weight) + (6.25 x height) - (4.92 x age) -161
<p><b>Sedentary</b> (<i>desk job, little: Sedentary (desk job, little to no exercise): Multiply RMR by 1.2
<p><b>Lightly Active</b> (<i>light exerc: Lightly Active (light exercise/sports 1-3 days/week): Multiply RMR by 1.375
<p><b>Moderately Active</b> (<i>moderate: Moderately Active (moderate exercise/sports 3-5 days/week): Multiply RMR by 1.55
<p><b>Very Active</b> (<i>hard daily exe: Very Active (hard daily exercise/sport 6-7 days/week): Multiply RMR by 1.725
<p><b>Extra Active</b> (hard daily exerc: Extra Active (hard daily exercise/sport, physically demanding job or training): Multiply RMR by 1.9

There is a method to this madness! Research shows that nutrient intake timing, along with consuming whole foods, can enhance your recovery, help build muscle protein, and balance your moods after high volume or intense activity (bonus)! 

Fueling and hydrating properly before a workout may help:
<p>Make sure blood sugars are in a targe: Make sure blood sugars are in a target range, meaning there's plenty of energy available to your muscles before they go to work.
<h2><b>Pre-Workout Meal (3-4 hours befor:
Pre-Workout Meal (3-4 hours before workout):

Everybody runs differently, but in general most athletes best tolerate a pre-workout meal 3-4 hours prior to activity time. In your pre-workout meal, it’s important to include carbs (your main fuel source) and protein (helps prime your muscles with the right amino acids). Remember the performance plate from the last activity? A pre-workout meal should be mainly carbs plus some color and protein. 

Some foods are more well-tolerated than others before a workout. It may be best to avoid the following foods in your pre-workout meal:
<p>High-fiber foods (high-fiber cereals,: High-fiber foods (high-fiber cereals, lentils, beans, cruciferous veggies like broccoli)
<p>High-fat foods (fried foods, cream-ba: High-fat foods (fried foods, cream-based dishes, high-fat desserts)
<p>Nut butter and jelly sandwich + banan: Nut butter and jelly sandwich + banana + low-fat milk
<p>Remember–each person is different and: Remember–each person is different and what upsets one person’s stomach might sit just fine with the next. It takes some trial and error to get it right, so make sure you pay attention to how you feel as you experiment with pre-workout meals!
<h2><b>Pre-Workout Snack (30 minutes - 2:
Pre-Workout Snack (30 minutes - 2 hours before workout):

Most high-performing athletes require snacks to bridge the hunger between meals. In fact, snacking twice a day (along with your three meals) can not only optimize your performance nutrition, but also improve muscle recovery and mental performance.

Snacking should be focused more on carbs and protein. Limit the fat and fiber to avoid upsetting your stomach right before workout time.

Timing is important here! If your pre-workout snack is 1-2 hours prior to workout time, you can balance more protein in with your carbs.  For example:
<p>But the closer you get to workout tim:
But the closer you get to workout time, the more your snack should be carb-focused. Remember–simple carbs are quickly absorbed into the bloodstream. That’s helpful before a workout because it means you have energy available! At other times of the day, when you don't need this fast energy, minimizing simple sugars is usually the healthiest way to optimize your blood sugar, energy levels, and overall health.

If you’re snacking 30-60 minutes prior to a workout, try simple carbs, like:
<p>Think back to foods you’ve consumed b: Think back to foods you’ve consumed before workouts. Which ones did your body tolerate best? Remember, there’s trial and error to find that out. Consider starting a food log where you list all the foods you’ve tested pre-workout and any symptoms that occur. This will help narrow down foods that should be your go-tos! Make notes of a few things in particular:

<h2>Strengthen Your Connections</h2><p>W:

When you’re feeling down or depressed, reaching out to others or socializing may feel like the last thing you want to do. You may feel anxious, unmotivated, or vulnerable, and you may find yourself isolating, even from those you care about.

Even though it might feel challenging, staying socially connected is one of the best things you can do to help reduce and prevent depression. It can help you cope when you’re feeling low. And knowing you have support and someone to depend on during tough times can be a great comfort.

Social connection doesn’t mean you have to go out to a big party or say yes to every invite you get. Here are a few small things you can try:

<p>Watch a movie or TV show with a frien: Watch a movie or TV show with a friend.
<p>Go for a walk with someone who brings: Go for a walk with someone who brings you joy.
<p>Say hello to someone in line at the g: Say hello to someone in line at the grocery store. Even this small gesture can make a difference in your mood.

<h2>Treatment Options for Depression</h2:
Treatment Options for Depression

There are several effective treatments for depression. It's important to know that help is available, and people do get better.

Common treatments include:
<p><b>Therapy:</b> Also called talk ther: Therapy: Also called talk therapy, this involves working with a mental health professional to address negative thoughts and develop coping skills.
<p><b>Medication:</b> Antidepressant med: Medication: Antidepressant medications can help regulate brain chemistry. It's crucial to consult with a healthcare provider to discuss medication options.
<p><b>Lifestyle Changes:</b> Changes lik: Lifestyle Changes: Changes like regular exercise, a healthy diet, and prioritizing sleep can significantly improve mood.
<p>In this activity, we'll explore commo: In this activity, we'll explore common treatment options, including therapy, medication, and lifestyle changes.
<h2>Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)</:
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)

CBT is a type of therapy that helps you identify and change negative thought patterns. For example, if you think “I'm worthless,” CBT can help you challenge that thought and replace it with a more balanced one.

Before we explore this further, tell us how you’re feeling today?
How have you felt throughout the day tod: How have you felt throughout the day today?
<h4>CBT focuses on the connection betwee:
CBT focuses on the connection between thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.

Example:
<p><b>Situation:</b> You receive constru: Situation: You receive constructive criticism at work.
<p><b>Automatic Thought:</b> <i>I'm goin: Automatic Thought: I'm going to get fired. I'm terrible at my job.
<p><b>Behavior:</b> Withdrawing from col: Behavior: Withdrawing from colleagues, avoiding work tasks.
<p>CBT helps you examine the evidence fo: CBT helps you examine the evidence for and against your automatic thought. Is there proof that only bad things happen to you? Or is there evidence that you also experience positive events?
<p>What first came to your mind in that: What first came to your mind in that situation?
<p>How did clarifying the situation chan: How did clarifying the situation change how you thought, felt, or acted toward the other person?
<p>If you’d chosen to accept your automa: If you’d chosen to accept your automatic thoughts without question, what do you think would’ve happened?
<h2>Try a Thought Record</h2><p>A though:
Try a Thought Record

A thought record is a tool used in CBT to track and challenge negative thoughts. Here's a simplified version:

Instructions:

  1. Think of a recent situation that made you feel down or anxious.
  2. Write down the automatic thought(s) that went through your mind.
  3. Identify the feeling associated with that thought (sad, angry, scared).
  4. Challenge the thought: Ask yourself, “What's the evidence for this thought? What's the evidence against it? Are there other ways of looking at the situation?”
  5. Write down a more balanced or realistic thought.
<p>This exercise can help you start to r: This exercise can help you start to recognize and change negative patterns.
<h3>Your CBT Step</h3><p>Pick one negati:
Your CBT Step

Pick one negative thought you notice today. Write it down. Then, write one possible alternative—don’t worry about ‘fixing’ it, just practice noticing and naming. You’ll get better every time you do it
<p>Pause and jot down the next negative: Pause and jot down the next negative thought you have. Done? You just completed the most important step in CBT!
<h2>Behavioral Activation</h2><p>Behavio:
Behavioral Activation

Behavioral activation involves increasing your engagement in activities that bring you joy and a sense of accomplishment. It's a technique often used in Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) to help people change their behavior patterns, overcome withdrawal, and improve their mood. 

It's not just about staying busy; it's about being intentional in your choices.

Examples of Behavioral Activation:
<p><b>Social:</b> Calling a friend, havi: Social: Calling a friend, having lunch with family, joining a club.
<p><b>Recreational:</b> Listening to mus: Recreational: Listening to music, reading a book, spending time in nature, pursuing a hobby.
<p><b>Self-Care:</b> Taking a bath, exer: Self-Care: Taking a bath, exercising, getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals.
<p><b>Accomplishment:</b> Completing a s: Accomplishment: Completing a small task, volunteering, learning a new skill.
<p>Engaging in these activities can help: Engaging in these activities can help break the cycle of withdrawal and inactivity that often comes with depression.

Plan an Activity

<h2>Problem-Solving Skills</h2><p><b>Pro:
Problem-Solving Skills

Problem-Solving Steps:

  1. Identify the Problem: Clearly define the issue you're facing.
  2. Brainstorm Solutions: Come up with as many solutions as possible, even if they seem unrealistic at first.
  3. Evaluate Solutions: Weigh the pros and cons of each solution.
  4. Choose a Solution: Select the solution that seems most feasible and effective.
  5. Implement the Solution: Put your chosen solution into action.
  6. Evaluate the Outcome: Assess whether the solution worked. If not, go back to step 3 and choose another solution.

Problem-Solving Example

Problem: “I've been feeling overwhelmed by household chores.”

Brainstormed Solutions:
<p><b>Chosen Solution:</b> Create a chor: Chosen Solution: Create a chore schedule and ask family members for help.
<p>This structured approach can make pro: This structured approach can make problems feel more manageable.
<p>To make problem-solving even more eff: To make problem-solving even more effective, try setting weekly goals related to the solutions you choose. Then, review your progress each week to see what's working and what needs adjustment. This can help you stay motivated and build momentum.
<h2>Understanding Medication</h2><p>Anti:
Understanding Medication

Antidepressants are a type of medication that can help treat depression. There are different classes, including SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors) and SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors).

Important: This program does not provide medication advice. Only a healthcare provider can determine if medication is right for you and prescribe it.
<h2>Understanding Antidepressants</h2><p:
Understanding Antidepressants

Antidepressants are medications that can help relieve symptoms of depression. They work by affecting chemicals in the brain called neurotransmitters.

It's important to remember that antidepressants are not a “quick fix” and usually take several weeks to start working.
<h2>Types of Antidepressants</h2><p>Ther:
Types of Antidepressants

There are several classes of antidepressants. Some common types include:
<p><b>Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhib: Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs): These are often the first medications prescribed for depression. Examples include fluoxetine (Prozac), sertraline (Zoloft), and escitalopram (Lexapro).
<p><b>Serotonin-Norepinephrine Reuptake: Serotonin-Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors (SNRIs): These medications increase both serotonin and norepinephrine. Examples include venlafaxine (Effexor XR) and duloxetine (Cymbalta).
<p><b>Other Antidepressants:</b> There a: Other Antidepressants: There are other types, such as bupropion (Wellbutrin) and mirtazapine (Remeron), which work differently.
<p>Each type of antidepressant has its o: Each type of antidepressant has its own potential benefits and side effects.
<h2>Benefits and Risks of Antidepressant:
Benefits and Risks of Antidepressants

Antidepressants can significantly improve mood, sleep, appetite, and energy levels for many people with depression.

However, they can also cause side effects. Common side effects include nausea, headache, sexual dysfunction, and sleep problems. These side effects are usually mild and temporary, but it is important to discuss them with your doctor.

It's crucial to weigh the potential benefits of antidepressants against the risks, in consultation with your healthcare provider.
<h2>Important Considerations for Antidep:
Important Considerations for Antidepressant Use

If your doctor prescribes antidepressants:

<h2>Why Weight Management?</h2><p>While:
Why Weight Management?

While it can be hard to precisely define a healthy weight for every person, carrying extra body weight over time can worsen OA symptoms by putting extra pressure on joints. Believe it or not, being 10 pounds overweight adds 15 to 50 pounds of pressure on your knees. 

While individuals of all body types develop arthritis, talk to your healthcare provider to understand if working toward a lower body weight can help reduce the pressure on your joints and slow the progression of arthritis. 

To learn more, read Why weight matters when it comes to joint pain.

<h2><b>Fuel Before Exercise</b></h2><p>T:
Fuel Before Exercise

There is a method to this madness! Research shows that nutrient intake timing, along with consuming whole foods, can enhance your recovery, help build muscle protein, and balance your moods after high volume or intense activity (bonus)! 

Fueling properly before a workout can help:
<h2><b>This one’s for the early risers.<:
This one’s for the early risers.

Everybody runs differently, but in general most athletes best tolerate a pre-workout meal 3-4 hours prior to activity time. If you’re a morning workout person, waking up to eat 3-4 hours before your activity just won’t work (we like our sleep, thanks)! 

To make sure you’re properly fueled (without a 3 a.m. wakeup call), try eating your “breakfast” the night before your early morning workout. This can help boost glycogen stores (fuel to help power your workout) and prevents low blood sugar in the morning, which can compromise performance. In the morning, all you’ll need is a light, carb-based snack and you’ll be fueled and ready to go. 

After-dinner “breakfast” ideas:
<p>Think back to foods you’ve consumed b: Think back to foods you’ve consumed before workouts. Which ones did your body tolerate best? Remember, there’s trial and error to find that out. Consider starting a food log where you list all the foods you’ve tested pre-workout and any symptoms that occur.  This will help narrow down foods that should be your go-tos! <h2><b>Know Your Hydration Strategy</b><:
Know Your Hydration Strategy

Water is an athlete's best friend and should never be left behind. Optimizing your athletic performance requires you to hydrate before, during, and after your workouts. (Sounds familiar?)

What does water do for your body?
<p>Helps eliminate waste products from t: Helps eliminate waste products from the body
<p>Too little water intake can lead to d: Too little water intake can lead to dehydration, which can majorly compromise performance. Always be on the lookout for signs of dehydration, like:
<p>Elevated heart rate, breathing rate,: Elevated heart rate, breathing rate, or body temperature
<h2><b>When and how much water to drink?:
When and how much water to drink?

Hydration is important before, during, and after exercise. Make sure you’re well-hydrated before a workout (drinking fluids with every meal can help keep you on track), drink to quench your thirst during a workout, and replenish what’s lost in sweat by drinking about 16oz water for every pound lost in sweat after a workout (see example below!) 

Weighing yourself before and after a workout is a quick way to evaluate your hydration status—and see how much you lost in sweat! Let’s say an athlete weighs 170lbs before a training session, and 167.5lbs after. That’s a 2.5lb sweat loss, so they should drink about 40oz (2.5 x 16oz) of water to replenish hydration. Spacing this out over several hours throughout the post-recovery period is the safest and best way to rehydrate.

Though it isn’t always 100% reliable, the color of your pee can be a quick indicator of hydration status. The goal should be pale yellow. Darker yellow generally indicates dehydration, while very light or almost clear urine may indicate overhydration. 

Important note: Although uncommon, it's possible to drink too much water (especially if you’re not including electrolytes when hydrating) – read on!
<h2><b>Don’t forget electrolytes!</b></h:
Don’t forget electrolytes!

Electrolytes are electrically charged minerals, like sodium, potassium, calcium, and magnesium, that help maintain fluid balance, muscle function, and energy production. 

Electrolytes can be lost in sweat and therefore need replacing! An intense workout (especially in a hot environment) can lead to significant electrolyte loss–this can be a big problem if we replace the water but not the electrolytes at the same time. Sports drinks or electrolyte tablets are a great option to rehydrate and add electrolytes back in, though they may only be needed for workouts that are 45-60 minutes or longer, or are in a hot and humid climate. If you wear heavy sports equipment or are a heavy or salty sweater, make sure to sip on electrolytes during and after a workout, along with water!
<h2><b>Practice your hydration.</b></h2>:
Practice your hydration.

Time to put this info to use! Start by getting an idea of how much you sweat by stepping on the scale before and after your next workout. Remember, it’s about 16oz water for every pound lost.  

How does your current hydration strategy stack up against the recommendations? It’s OK if you aren’t hitting these targets (a lot of people don’t). Here are a few ideas you can try to help increase your water intake:
<p>Switch it up with a jug of water infu: Switch it up with a jug of water infused with cucumber or the zest of your favorite citrus fruit.
<p>Freeze some ice cubes with mint, lime: Freeze some ice cubes with mint, lime, or any other fun flavors to throw into your next glass.
<p>Set reminder alarms on your watch or: Set reminder alarms on your watch or phone to take sips before, during, and after your workout.
<p>Start low, go slow, and remember thos:
Start low, go slow, and remember those electrolytes! One sip at a time! Check in with a sports dietitian for a more tailored plan to meet your personal hydration needs. 

Important note: If you find weighing yourself to be triggering, skip that step! Instead, focus on drinking water before, during, and after a workout–enough for your pee to be a pale yellow. Remember, that’s a pretty good indication of optimal hydration! (And, don’t forget the electrolytes!)

<h2><b>Fuel During Exercise</b></h2><p>R:
Fuel During Exercise

Refueling properly during prolonged moderate- to vigorous-intensity exercise (60 minutes or longer) will help maintain blood sugar, which keeps energy flowing to working muscles and prevents fatigue. 

During physical activity, your body uses carbs from glycogen stores as energy. As these glycogen stores are used up, during a prolonged workout for example, your body starts relying on other forms of energy, like fats, which can be less efficient. Refueling with carbs during a long workout replenishes blood sugar and feeds your muscles. This prevents muscle fatigue, keeps skills and coordination intact, and reduces the risk of injury. Plus, carbs fuel your brain, which maintains mental stamina, allowing you to work out longer and harder!  

The amount of replenishing needed depends on the length and intensity of your workout. The longer and more intense the activity, the greater the refueling requirements will be.
<h2><b>Let’s break things down:</b></h2>:
Let’s break things down:

Eating or drinking large amounts can upset your stomach during a workout, so beware! It’s best to start with small sips and bites until you learn what works best for you. Let’s look at how to refuel properly during different types of activities:

  • Workouts lasting 1 hours - 2.5 hours
    • Activity examples: Long-distance running, swim practice, bike rides, soccer games
    • Refuel rate: 30-60g of carbs (about 120-240 calories) per hour after the first hour of exercise
    • Snack ideas: Sports drink, gels, or beans; pretzels; crackers; banana
  • Low- to Moderate-intensity workouts lasting longer than 2.5 hours
    • Activity examples: Marathon walking, hiking, moderately intense bike rides
    • Refuel rate: At least 30g of carbs (about 120 calories) per hour after the first hour of activity
    • Snack ideas: Sports drink, gels, or beans; granola bars; energy bars; banana; dried fruit
  • Higher-intensity workouts lasting longer than 2.5 hours
    • Activity examples: Running a marathon, ultramarathon, triathlon
    • Refuel rate: 60-90g of carbs (240-360 calories) per hour
    • Snack ideas: Sports drink, gels, or beans; granola bars; energy bars; banana; dried fruit; cookies
    • Hydration is also key here–more on that coming up!
<h2><b>Strive for variety.</b></h2><p>Th:
Strive for variety.

The body absorbs and transports different types of sugar, like glucose and fructose, in different ways. By consuming carbs from a variety of food and fluid sources, your body will use different transporter systems, allowing for higher carb absorption overall. Remember, more carbs = more energy.

Today, add some mid-workout fuel sources to your grocery list! As mentioned in the last activity, consider starting a food log and note which foods work (and don’t work) during your training sessions. Before you know it, you’ll be a fueling pro!

Important note: In warmer climates or during more intense exercise, carbohydrate intake can sometimes be harder to tolerate. On these days, focus on fluid replacement. Every athlete operates differently and it may take some time to find out what works best for you. Work with a sports dietitian if you have specific questions or concerns.

<h2><b>Refuel and Replenish After Exerci:
Refuel and Replenish After Exercise

The post-training recovery phase remains a hot topic for researchers. Your immediate post-workout goals should be to:
<p><b>Repair and build </b>muscles with: Repair and build muscles with high quality protein.
<p><b>Replenish</b> hydration status wit: Replenish hydration status with fluids and electrolytes.
<p>If possible, you should refuel as ear:
If possible, you should refuel as early as 30 minutes - 2 hours after your workout to take advantage of your recovery window. It’s within this time period when your muscle cells can use carbs and proteins most efficiently and effectively. Optimizing your recovery is even more important if you’re training twice a day.

Don’t stress too much if you miss this small window, as your muscles will continue to respond to the nutrients you feed them throughout the next 24 hours. If your appetite is normally low right after a workout, try liquid food options like smoothies or shakes.
<h2><b>What to eat after a workout.</b><:
What to eat after a workout.

The general rule of thumb for post-workout nutrition is a 3:1 ratio of carbs to protein. In other words, your meal or snack should be carb-heavy but include some protein as well. Here are a few ideas of what that might look like:
<p>Peanut butter and jelly sandwich + fr: Peanut butter and jelly sandwich + fruit or yogurt
<p>Granola bar or handful of nuts + choc: Granola bar or handful of nuts + chocolate milk
<p>Snack plate (apple slices, string che: Snack plate (apple slices, string cheese, pretzels, and peanut butter)
<p>Burrito bowl (rice, chicken or tofu,: Burrito bowl (rice, chicken or tofu, black beans, salsa, lettuce, and shredded cheese)
<h2><b>Spend a few minutes planning.</b>:
Spend a few minutes planning.

Today, take a few minutes to plan out your recovery strategy. Look at your training schedule and plan a post-workout snack that’s realistic for you. For example, if you workout in the morning, plan something that’s easy to eat on your way into work! Going from your workout to a child’s practice? Pack a cooler with a few snacks! This little bit of planning will help ensure you’ve always got refueling options on hand (plus, no one likes being hangry).

<p>If this is all new to you and feels o:
If this is all new to you and feels overwhelming to do all at once, that’s OK! When you’re making any health-related change, it’s best to do it in bite-sized chunks and focus your attention on one area at a time. Think about your nutrition and training habits. What’s one area you’d like to improve upon? 

For example, if you routinely train on an empty stomach and feel drained during your workouts, maybe start by zoning in on your pre-workout meal. If you’re on-the-go right after your workouts, maybe it’s best to focus on your refueling strategy. Let’s look at an example on the next page.
Let’s look to Lisa as an example.

Lisa usually works out at the gym before work. When she completes her workout, she rushes to get ready for the day and out the door. She hits the ground running when she gets to work and doesn’t realize how hungry she is until lunchtime! 

Sound somewhat familiar? Though Lisa’s lunch will still help refuel her body, she could definitely benefit from having a meal or snack sooner after her workout. Since she’s busy and on the go, here’s a few realistic solutions for Lisa:
<p>She could pack a lunchbox the night b: She could pack a lunchbox the night before with a granola bar and chocolate milk that she can have on the way to work.
<p>She could keep oatmeal packets, yogur: She could keep oatmeal packets, yogurt, and fruit at work to eat mid-morning once she’s settled in.
<p>Just a few small changes can make all: Just a few small changes can make all the difference in optimizing your nutrition strategy! Rather than trying to do it all, identify one change you’d like to make and come up with a realistic plan to make it happen. Remember–it might take a bit of trial and error. That’s all part of the process. You’ll get there, we promise!

<h2>Protect Your Joints</h2><p>It can be:
Protect Your Joints

It can be frustrating when arthritis affects your everyday life. Here are a few tips to help you reduce aches and pains, improve mobility, and protect your joints over the long term.
<h2>Wear Proper Shoes</h2><p>Just like t:
Wear Proper Shoes

Just like the foods we eat or activities we do, the choices we make for our feet can also have lasting impacts on our health. Keep hip, knee, or foot pain at bay and reduce injury or reinjury to joints with the following suggestions:
<p><b>Swap high heels for flats. </b>Thr: Swap high heels for flats. Three-inch heels can cause 7 times more stress on your foot than a 1-inch heel.
<p><b>Ensure that your shoes are comfort: Ensure that your shoes are comfortable. Seems like a no-brainer, but your kicks should allow enough room for your toes to move freely inside the shoe and have adequate arch support and cushioning. There is an ongoing debate about whether flexible flats or more supportive stability shoes are preferred for reducing knee load. Try a few different styles and see what works best for you!
<h2>Keep Moving</h2><p>Moving for at lea:
Keep Moving

Moving for at least a few minutes, many times throughout the day, is important for not just joint health but overall health. Whether you’re at home or work, try to get up or change positions every 30 minutes or so to prevent stiffness. Here are some tips to help you be more active:
<p>Stand or walk when taking a phone cal: Stand or walk when taking a phone call.
<p>Use your calendar to schedule walks o: Use your calendar to schedule walks or times you want to incorporate movement.
<p>While you watch TV, walk around the h: While you watch TV, walk around the house or bring out the resistance bands during commercials.
<h2>Eat a Healthy Diet</h2><p>Eating a d:
Eat a Healthy Diet

Eating a diet full of fiber, vitamins, omega-3 fatty acids, and healthy fats has many benefits to overall health. Though it isn’t clear if diet helps with symptoms of osteoarthritis, it can help with weight management, which can ease pressure on your joints. 

Alternatively, if your day consists of many repetitive activities, make sure you take breaks and stretch your muscles.
<p>Every person has unique nutritional n: Every person has unique nutritional needs. If you have questions or concerns about your diet, or are planning to make changes to your nutrition habits, talk to your healthcare provider. This is especially true if you've been previously diagnosed with a chronic health condition such as kidney disease, heart disease, or a gastrointestinal disease; are taking prescription medications; or are planning to start a new vitamin or supplement. Your provider can help ensure you're making safe and healthy dietary choices and work with you to create a plan that's right for you.

<h2>Learn About Arthritis</h2><p>Welcome:
Learn About Arthritis

Welcome to the Living with Osteoarthritis program! Osteoarthritis (OA) is a painful condition that makes it tough to participate in and enjoy everyday activities. But through this program you'll learn strategies for easing discomfort, protecting your joints from injury and other helpful tips.
<h2>What is osteoarthritis (OA)?</h2><p>:
What is osteoarthritis (OA)?

Arthritis is a condition that involves inflammation or a breakdown of joint tissues–that is, bone and cartilage. Osteoarthritis is the most common form of arthritis, affecting the entire joint (bone, cartilage, ligaments, fat and tissues lining the joint). This degenerative disease can cause changes in the shape of the bone, reduce cartilage and cause inflammation.

Did you know that cartilage is important for mobility and protection when it comes to activity, weight distribution and acts as a cushion between joints and bones? No surprise then that OA typically presents as pain, stiffness, or reduced mobility to joints like the neck, back, shoulders, knees, hips, hands, or feet. 

There are many other types of arthritis that can affect joints as well. Talk to your healthcare provider if you have any concerns, to review your diagnosis and treatment options.
<h3>What causes osteoarthritis (OA)?</h3:
What causes osteoarthritis (OA)?

OA was commonly known as a “wear and tear” condition with being common in those 50 years and older, but it can affect younger people too. There are many contributing factors to this degenerative joint disease, including:
<p>Gender- women are more likely to deve: Gender- women are more likely to develop OA
<p>Modifiable factors such as obesity, o: Modifiable factors such as obesity, occupation, level of physical activity
<h3>How does osteoarthritis (OA) impact:
How does osteoarthritis (OA) impact day to day activities?

Because of the pain associated with OA, you may, over time, need to change the way you complete certain daily activities, such as exercise, work, and household chores. In some cases, people choose to move to homes without stairs or renovate their current home to accommodate their changing mobility.

OA can also affect your mood, ability to get a good night’s sleep, and enjoyment of certain activities, which may become harder to do or more uncomfortable. It’s important for people with OA to have a good support network with whom they can vent about their day-to-day struggles and celebrate their successes. Support can be found in:
<p>Support groups for people with OA (on: Support groups for people with OA (online or in person)
<p>For most people, the goals of treatin:
For most people, the goals of treating arthritis include reducing pain, minimizing joint damage, and improving or maintaining function and quality of life. It may seem overwhelming, but there are ways to help you feel better!

Throughout this program we will discuss ways to help better manage your arthritis.

<h2>Know Your Meds - It’s All About Suga:
Know Your Meds - It’s All About Sugar

These medications are focused on managing glucose directly! They work to remove extra glucose or slow your body from making too much glucose.
<p><b>Sugar Removers:</b> These meds are: Sugar Removers: These meds are the cleanup crew for extra sugar in the body. Meds like canagliflozin or empagliflozin help the kidneys push more sugar into your urine, so it doesn’t stay in your body.
<p><b>Sugar Release Regulators:</b> Metf: Sugar Release Regulators: Metformin is the most common medication for T2D and the only one of its kind. It controls blood sugar in a few ways. When the liver (aka the body’s sugar factory) makes too much sugar, metformin slows it down. It also slows the uptake of sugar from foods and makes the body more sensitive to insulin. This prevents sugar spikes after eating.
<p><b>&nbsp;</b>Medication should always:
Medication should always be taken as prescribed by your healthcare provider. If you're unable to take your medication as directed, wish to adjust the dose, or have questions, contact your healthcare provider to discuss.

<h2>Know Your Meds - All About Insulin&n:
Know Your Meds - All About Insulin 

These medications are all focused on the actions and impacts of insulin. Insulin lowers blood sugar by making your body cells absorb glucose from the bloodstream. Sometimes our bodies don’t produce enough insulin to do this properly and need some help. This is an example of how meds can play a part in your diabetes management.
<p><b>Insulin Stimulator/Sugar Regulator: Insulin Stimulator/Sugar Regulators: These meds give double the benefit by helping to make more insulin and by reducing sugar production in the liver. It’s like a one-two punch, to keep your sugar levels in check! Examples include sitagliptin and linagliptin.
<p><b>Insulin Boosters:</b> Insulin is e: Insulin Boosters: Insulin is extremely important when it comes to keeping blood sugars stable in T2D. These medications work to increase your body’s own production of insulin. They are usually taken with meals to help lower any spikes in blood sugar. Some examples include gliclazide and glyburide.
<p><b>Insulin Sensitizers:</b> Medicatio: Insulin Sensitizers: Medications like pioglitazone are less commonly used. They can help manage T2D by making the body more sensitive to insulin. By increasing insulin sensitivity, the body is able to take up more sugar and use it for energy instead of letting it stay in the blood.
<p><b>Hormone Mimickers:</b> Semaglutide: Hormone Mimickers: Semaglutide is part of this newer category of T2D medications. It works by copying the actions of a hormone in the body that is responsible for stimulating insulin release, controlling hunger, and slowing down the time it takes to break down food.

<h2>Exercise &amp; Arthritis</h2><p><b>W:
Exercise & Arthritis

Why: Physical activity plays an important role in both mental and physical health. When it comes to joints in particular, regular activity helps keep them strong, lubricates the cartilage, and reduces stiffness and pain. And as a bonus, exercise can also help with energy levels, boost the release of happy chemicals in the brain (dopamine), and help you manage your weight. 

Finding the right balance is key for managing arthritis symptoms. Physical activity helps reduce pain and stiffness, but it’s also important to listen to your body so you’re doing the right activities and don’t strain your joints too much. And, don’t forget to rest and take time to recover if your arthritis flares!

You can also make it fun! Meet people for group exercises and use the time to chat with a friend or family member or simply just get out and about.
<p><b>Exercise has many benefits if you:
Exercise has many benefits if you have arthritis, such as:

  1. Preserving or restoring range of motion and flexibility
  2. Increasing muscle strength and endurance
  3. Improving mood
  4. Decreasing other health risks associated with inactivity.

Find exercises or activities that you enjoy and fit within your abilities. For example, the best types of aerobic exercise (activities that are meant to increase your heart rate) don’t put too much stress on the joints or involve a lot of twisting or turning. These low impact or low stress options typically include walking, cycling, swimming, water aerobics, light gardening, group exercise classes, and casual dancing around your home.  

Muscle-strengthening exercises can be done with weights, resistance bands or yoga.

Flexibility exercises, like yoga, help maintain range of motion so that you can continue doing regular household activities and hobbies. 

Balance exercises are helpful especially if you’re concerned about falling or have difficulty walking. Yoga and tai chi both help with balance.
<h2>Getting Started</h2><p>The CDC recom:
Getting Started

The CDC recommends a mix of physical activity, including those impacted by arthritis. This includes at least 150 minutes weekly of moderate aerobic activity and at least 2 days per week of muscle-strengthening activites. Remember exercise should be directed toward the entire body, not just arthritic joints. As you start your routine, record how your symptoms feel when you’re active using the 3 WHATS.
<p>You can usually identify patterns aft:
You can usually identify patterns after a few weeks! 

If you’re just beginning to exercise, it’s important to pick an activity that feels comfortable, and then start with short sessions. 

The acronym S.M.A.R.T can help to support people starting to exercise to help ease arthritis symptoms.
<p><b>S: </b>Start Low, Go Slow (3-5 min: S: Start Low, Go Slow (3-5 minutes of activity 2 times a day to start)
<p><b>M: </b>Modify activities if your s: M: Modify activities if your symptoms get worse, while still trying to keep up some level of activity. (On good days and bad days, try to find a comfortable level of intensity to stay as active as possible without making yourself feel worse.)
<p><b>A: </b>Activities should be joint: A: Activities should be joint friendly when possible (such as walking, bicycling, water aerobics, easy dancing around the home, or yoga)
<p><b>R: </b>Recognize safe places and w: R: Recognize safe places and ways to be active. (For example, an exercise class led by a trained instructor or sidewalks or pathways that are level, free of obstructions, non-slip, and well-lit.).
<p><b>T: </b>Talk to a health profession: T: Talk to a health professional or certified exercise specialist for ideas about activities that match your abilities, daily routines, and health goals.
<h2>What do I do if I feel pain during o:
What do I do if I feel pain during or after exercise?

If you do have some initial pain or stiffness, you can try some of these tips:
<p>Modify your physical activity to redu: Modify your physical activity to reduce the impact on your joint by changing the type or frequency or duration of exercise.
<p>Do an active warm-up and cool-down be: Do an active warm-up and cool-down before and after exercising to improve flexibility and reduce the risk of injury.
<p>Keep your exercise to a gentle, comfo: Keep your exercise to a gentle, comfortable pace–you should still be able to have a casual conversation.
<p>Make sure you have well fitting and c: Make sure you have well fitting and comfortable shoes.
<p>If pain or other symptoms are severe,: If pain or other symptoms are severe, contact your healthcare provider.
<p>You may benefit from some additional: You may benefit from some additional support. Try working with a personal trainer, physical therapist, or physiotherapist to develop an exercise routine that fits your needs and situation! There are many joint-friendly exercise programs available—some of which may be accessible within your community. Ask your healthcare provider if there are any in your area.
<p>Before starting a new exercise progra:
Before starting a new exercise program or changing your existing habits, speak with a healthcare provider to ensure it's safe for you. This is particularly important for individuals who have a known musculoskeletal, heart, or lung condition.

If at any time you experience new or worsening symptoms while exercising, contact your healthcare provider right away or go to your nearest emergency department. Symptoms requiring urgent attention include chest pain, shortness of breath, swelling in your legs, confusion, sudden changes in exercise tolerance, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, palpitations, or excessive fatigue.

<h2>Know the Types of Therapy</h2><p>The:
Know the Types of Therapy

There may not yet be a cure for arthritis, but there are treatments that can help manage your symptoms–and make life more enjoyable! Talk with your primary care provider about whether any of these treatment plans might be right for you.

At-Home Remedies:
Doing exercises like yoga and tai-chi help keep your joints moving freely. And, when your joint pain flares up, try using heat or cold packs to take the edge off (most people find that warm works best). You can also practice mindfulness, deep breathing, or finding other distractions to help you cope with pain. 

Medications:
The most common medications used to reduce inflammation are nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as naproxen or ibuprofen. You can take them as pills or apply them to the skin over the joint as a gel or cream–but talk to your healthcare provider to ensure these are safe for you. If over-the-counter medications aren’t enough to help manage pain and inflammation, your healthcare provider might recommend cortisone (steroid) injections into the affected joint or other pain and anti-inflamatory medications. 

Physical Therapy:
Therapists can teach you how to adjust your daily activities to lessen your pain and improve strength, range of motion, and overall mobility. They’ll also teach you exercises or stretches that help your joints feel their best. 

Surgery:
Joint replacement or repair might be considered for knee, shoulder, or hip arthritis if your symptoms worsen despite other treatments. If your symptoms stay severe, these surgeries can significantly relieve pain and help people get back to their usual activities.
<p>It’s important to speak regularly wit: It’s important to speak regularly with your healthcare provider about your symptoms so they can help you build a treatment plan that’s right for you. Sometimes you might need to try a few different therapies or combinations to find what works best for your situation.

<h2>Take Care While Traveling</h2><p>Don:
Take Care While Traveling

Don’t let pain keep you from going places. Keep these tips in mind to make your next travels a little easier and less stressful:

Request accommodations if needed.

  • Plan activities ahead of time and choose ones that work with your body and abilities. 
  • Check to see if your hotel has a pool, hot tub, or sauna where you can go to rejuvenate your joints.
  • Call ahead to check accessibility options and accommodations for guests. 
    • Ask for a room close to the elevator or on the ground floor if walking or climbing steps are a challenge. 

Plan ahead when possible.

Know what is comfortable for you when planning your itinerary, including: 

  • How far you can walk
  • How many bags you can carry
  • Whether or not you’ll need assistance with your luggage

If you’re flying, consider requesting early boarding, a wheelchair, or a seat near the restroom. 

If you’re driving, consider packing a portable heating pad that plugs into your car. Have plastic bags ready if you need to apply ice to affected joints. Map out your pitstops to get out of the car and stretch regularly. Lastly, plan to rest and recover once you arrive at your destination. 

Keep your meds handy
If you’re flying, pack your medications in your carry-on, in their original containers,  in a large plastic bag. 

Pack wisely
Prepare not only for the weather but also the journey. Whether you’re driving or flying, you may want to consider bringing a neck or lumbar support pillow, and remember to pack any braces or assistive devices you use regularly. 

Manage your stress
Stress is not friendly to our muscles and joints. It’s often the culprit of unwanted stiffness and pain. When traveling, minimize impact by using luggage with wheels, checking your bags when possible, bringing hot and cold wraps, getting up and moving regularly to avoid stiffness and pain, and drinking plenty of water.

Remember, eat your pre-exercise meal 3-4 hours prior to activity, if possible. This meal or snack should be enough to carry you through your entire workout.

Protect Yourself From Shingles and Pneum: Protect Yourself From Shingles and Pneumonia
<h2>Protect Yourself From Shingles and P:
Protect Yourself From Shingles and Pneumonia

As we get older, our immune systems are less able to fight off major infections. But some infections are preventable, such as shingles and pneumonia. These are some of the most important vaccines to get.

Shingles is a rash that can be quite painful. It is caused by the varicella zoster virus, which also causes chicken pox. For some people, the pain can last weeks or months, even once the rash has healed. It can be a major concern if it affects the face, as this can impact the eye and vision.

Shingles vaccines can reduce the likelihood of getting shingles. Two doses of the vaccine are recommended for best protection, usually after age 50 for most people. Ask your healthcare provider what they recommend for you.
<h2>How Pneumonia Vaccines Protect You</:
How Pneumonia Vaccines Protect You

Pneumonia is an infection of the lungs, which causes them to fill with fluid. Some types are caused by bacteria, which can be treated with antibiotics. However, recovery is often slow and pneumonia can render people more vulnerable to getting sick.

Fortunately, pneumonia vaccines can be effective at protecting against infection from one of the most common types of bacteria that cause pneumonia. They are recommended for ages 65 and older, or for those with certain chronic conditions (such as diabetes, asthma, or emphysema, or (COPD). Talk to your provider about what they recommend for you.

Vaccines do more than just keep you healthy, they keep the people you are around safe and healthy too.

Shielding Babies and Moms to Be:

Babies are tiny and fragile, and so is their immune system. They can’t fight off certain germs or viruses as easily as you can. When you’re vaccinated, you create a safety net around them. This small act helps prevent passing viruses, and helps keep babies healthy and happy.
<p><b>Guarding Others:</b></p><p>Think a:

Think about your grandparents or an older family member. As people age, they may not have the same strong immune system they did when they were younger. By staying up-to-date on your shots, you lower the risk of passing along any viruses like the flu or shingles to them.

By being vaccinated, you help create a protective barrier around these vulnerable individuals.

Simple things, like a cut or a scrape, can result in life-threatening infections from bacteria that get into our body. One of these bacteria, called Clostridium tetani, is all around us—in dust, soil and dirt—can enter these small wounds and cause major complications, and even death.

Because it’s hard to totally prevent getting cuts and scrapes, keeping up with the tetanus vaccine can significantly reduce the risk of getting infected by the tetanus bacteria.

Your tetanus vaccine should be repeated every 10 years. It can be hard to keep track of this one, so keep records of your most recent dose. (Or ask your provider to give you a copy of their records.)

<h2>Learn How Vaccines Keep You Safe</h2:
Learn How Vaccines Keep You Safe

Vaccines have had a huge impact on reducing the likelihood of getting sick from major diseases caused by bacteria and viruses. They are one of the most important ways to improve and protect our health and well-being. They have extended our life spans, and protect those who are most vulnerable to infection, including newborns, young children, and older individuals. Many infectious diseases that used to cause widespread disease, make many people sick, and cause death or life-long disability, are now much more rare thanks to vaccines.
<p><b>History of Vaccines</b></p><p>For:
History of Vaccines

For example, before the vaccine against the polio virus was introduced in 1988, up to 1000 children were paralyzed by the virus every day. Since then (and after the delivery of almost 3 billion doses of the vaccine), the virus has been eliminated in most countries around the world, including across North America. (But, getting the polio vaccine in childhood is still important to keep it from coming back!)

And newer vaccines are even having major impacts on reducing other diseases, such as the impact of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine on cancer rates. This vaccine improves our immune response to HPV, and research shows that it reduces the risk of cervical cancer by 80-90%, without any major side effects. Did you know the HPV vaccine also provides important protection for males too, including reducing the risk of HPV-related head and neck cancers by up to 55%. Pretty amazing! Fortunately, these vaccines all have been closely studied to ensure their effectiveness, and also monitor for side effects that emerge.

Read on to learn about which vaccines are important to stay healthy in adulthood! And, always talk to your healthcare provider to review which recommendations best apply in your situation.

<h2>Common Side Effects</h2><p>As with a:
Common Side Effects

As with any medication, oral T2D pills may cause side effects. Here’s a list of the most common side effects associated with each category of T2D medication.

Sugar removers, like canagliflozin or empagliflozin, can increase your chance of a urinary tract infection. Some ways to help prevent UTIs include:
<p>Practicing good hygiene in the genita: Practicing good hygiene in the genital area
<p>If you are sexually active, make sure: If you are sexually active, make sure to void before and after sex
<p>Report any signs of infection to your: Report any signs of infection to your doctor for proper treatment. These include:
<p>Urgency to urinate, even if your blad: Urgency to urinate, even if your bladder is empty
<p><b>Sugar release regulators</b>, like: Sugar release regulators, like metformin, can sometimes cause stomach issues. Diarrhea and nausea are most common when first starting metformin. Remember to always take metformin with food to help prevent any stomach upset.
<p><b>Insulin stimulators/sugar regulato: Insulin stimulators/sugar regulators, like sitagliptin and linagliptin, are less associated with side effects. In rare circumstances, these meds can cause headache, runny nose and a sore throat. If this happens to you, make sure to get plenty of rest and stay hydrated. These unpleasant symptoms usually go away on their own but if they persist, contact your healthcare provider.
<p><b>Insulin boosters</b>, like gliclaz: Insulin boosters, like gliclazide and glyburide, most commonly cause low blood sugar, especially if too much insulin is produced. Feeling shaky, sweaty, and tired are all signs that your body may be too low on sugar. If using these meds, it’s wise to carry a sugary snack/drink in case this happens to you. For example, if you feel any of these symptoms, drink a juice box or have a few candies to help raise your blood sugar.
<p><b>Insulin sensitizers</b>, like piog: Insulin sensitizers, like pioglitazone, can cause swelling of your face, hands, legs and feet. Limit the amount of salt you eat to help manage the swelling. If the swelling worsens or comes on suddenly, contact your doctor.
<p><b>Hormone mimickers</b>, like semagl: Hormone mimickers, like semaglutide, may cause you to feel sick or throw up at first. These symptoms usually go away with time but eating smaller meals more frequently can help prevent throwing up. If you find you are vomiting often and unable to keep food or drinks down, contact your healthcare provider.
<h2>Know the Signs and Symptoms</h2><p>I:
Know the Signs and Symptoms

If you notice any of these side effects or generally feel unwell after starting a new medication, don’t hesitate to contact your healthcare provider. They can provide you with additional information on how to manage these side effects in the best way possible. See your provider right away if you experience the following:
<p>Severe stomach pain that doesn’t go a: Severe stomach pain that doesn’t go away

<h2>Tips for Staying on Track</h2><p>Tak:
Tips for Staying on Track

Taking your diabetes medications as prescribed by your provider is a roadmap for good health. In the long run, being consistent with your medications helps manage your sugars, which prevents further complications like heart attacks, stroke, or vision problems to name a few. 

We know it can be hard to stick to your medications when there are multiple and you have to take them at different times! If you’re facing challenges or want some help with different tools to stay on track with your meds, speak with your local pharmacist! But in the meantime, check out and try some of our tips.
<p>Here are some helpful tips:</p><ol><l:
Here are some helpful tips:

  1. Refills reminders/automatic refills: Ask your pharmacy to send you a reminder for when your next refill is due. Some pharmacies will even offer to automatically refill your prescription a few days before you run out, so that you always have a supply of your meds.
  2. Medication organizer: Keep your meds organized in a weekly pill organizer. A quick glance will let you know if you’ve taken all your pills for the day. You can do this yourself or ask your pharmacist to organize your meds for you into a daily pack instead of in pill bottles. 
  3. Keep medications visible: Store your medications in a place where you’ll see them regularly. A good spot could be the kitchen or bedside table. Having a visual reminder will ensure they aren’t “out of sight and out of mind”. Just make sure that if you have young children around, that the medications aren’t accessible to them!

<h2>Foot Exams</h2><p>Periodic foot chec:
Foot Exams

Periodic foot checks are an important way people with diabetes can make sure their skin and nerves are healthy. You’ll want to check your hands and feet closely and often, like once a day, at the same time every day. It often helps to pair these foot checks with another habit, like when you put on your socks. Look for cuts, scrapes, swelling, sores and signs of infection, such as redness. Your provider will also likely want to check your hands and feet during appointments.

It can be hard to feel sensations on your skin due to diabetes. Be sure to also keep your care team up-to-date on any signs of nerve damage you experience. Keep note of things like numbness, tingling or any other changes in sensation throughout your body, and particularly in your feet.

<h2>Cholesterol Tests</h2><p>Because hig:
Cholesterol Tests

Because high blood sugars can damage your arteries, this can make it more likely that you will have high cholesterol. This raises your risk of heart attack and stroke.

Diabetes also tends to lower “good” cholesterol levels (also known as HDL) and raise triglycerides (fat) and “bad” cholesterol levels (LDL). This increases the risk for heart disease and stroke as well.

Hold on a minute, you might be thinking. I have diabetes, but my cholesterol is fine. That may be the case. But your provider will probably still want to monitor you regularly, probably every six to 12 months.
<p>To check your cholesterol, medical pr:
To check your cholesterol, medical professionals will usually order a blood test. Your test will measure the amount of “good” and “bad” cholesterol as well as triglycerides in your blood. It will also give you a total cholesterol number, which represents the total level of cholesterol in your blood.

Medical professionals will be checking to see if your “bad” cholesterol is too high. If it is, they will likely start you on medication to bring it down to healthy levels. Your provider will then monitor you to see if your condition is improving or if you need to change treatment.
<p><b>I have high cholesterol. Now what?:
I have high cholesterol. Now what?

High cholesterol is common for people with high blood sugar. If you have diabetes, you might have different ranges for what’s healthy. Always check in with your provider about your levels and what they might mean.

Your provider can help you develop a plan for how to get your cholesterol levels to a healthy range. This might include:

<h2>Weight and Waist Measurements</h2><p:
Weight and Waist Measurements

For people with diabetes, carrying extra weight can cause health challenges. Excess weight can make your body use insulin less effectively, which makes it harder to control your blood sugar.

Changes in waist circumference (the length around your waistline, just above your belly button) can also put you at risk, even if you don’t carry extra weight.

So how can you reduce your risk of health problems? Focusing on regular healthy habits and medication management (not the scale) is your best bet.

Your doctor will be able to tell you what a healthy weight and waist measurement is for you. Staying in a healthy range and checking in regularly with your doctor will help manage your condition.

<h2>Blood Pressure Tests</h2><p>The more:
Blood Pressure Tests

The more sugar in your blood, the more stiff and narrow your vessels will become.

Damaged blood vessels mean high blood pressure, which can have serious risks for your health. High blood pressure can increase your chance of stroke, kidney disease and heart attack.

So how can you prevent all this? Tracking your blood pressure is a good start. Even people who don’t have high blood pressure should check often, since having diabetes puts you at increased risk. Let’s learn how.
<p><b>How to measure</b></p><p>Your bloo:
How to measure

Your blood pressure levels can be taken in your doctor’s office or at home with a blood pressure cuff. When you’re taking a reading, make sure to:
<p>Sit in a comfortable chair with back: Sit in a comfortable chair with back support for at least five minutes before your reading.
<p>Put both feet flat on the ground and: Put both feet flat on the ground and keep your legs uncrossed.
<p>Rest your arm with the cuff on a tabl: Rest your arm with the cuff on a table at chest height.
<p>Make sure the blood pressure cuff is: Make sure the blood pressure cuff is snug but not too tight. The cuff should be against your bare skin, not over clothing.
<p>You’ll also want to empty your bladde:
You’ll also want to empty your bladder and avoid eating for up to 30 minutes before you test to get an accurate reading.

What should my levels look like?

A healthy level for most adults with diabetes is under 130/80 mmHg.
<p>Your provider will likely monitor you: Your provider will likely monitor your blood pressure, but there are ways to keep your blood pressure healthy between visits. These include:
<p>Finding healthy ways to manage your s: Finding healthy ways to manage your stress
<p>Moving your body on the regular (chec: Moving your body on the regular (check in with your provider to find a schedule that works for you)

<h2>Kidney Health Tests</h2><p>High bloo:
Kidney Health Tests

High blood sugar can harm your kidneys over time.

Kidney function tests help track how well your kidneys are working. They can be ordered by your provider or someone else on your diabetes care team.

Up to three out of 10 people with type 1 diabetes will develop kidney disease.  Screenings can help you and your doctor make medication or lifestyle changes to keep your kidneys healthy.
<p><b>What kinds of kidney tests are usu:
What kinds of kidney tests are usually done?
There are two types of tests for kidney function.
<p><b>An ACR test. </b>If you have prote: An ACR test. If you have protein in your urine, it could mean you have kidney disease. These tests measure the amount of protein in your urine through a urine sample. Providers use ACR tests to find out whether kidney damage or kidney disease is getting worse.
<p><b>An eGFR test. </b>This is a calcul: An eGFR test. This is a calculation to see how well your kidneys are functioning. The higher the number, the better your function. Low numbers can mean kidney disease (but not always).
<p><b>My test results aren’t normal. Now:
My test results aren’t normal. Now what?

First, don’t panic. A low result doesn’t always mean you have chronic kidney disease. Working on keeping your blood sugar within a healthy range can also help slow kidney disease if you do have it. Talk with your provider about next steps to keep your kidneys in tip-top shape.

<h2>Monitoring With Blood Tests</h2><p>W:
Monitoring With Blood Tests

When it comes to diabetes, tracking your blood sugar (also known as glucose) is one of the most important things you can do.

People with diabetes or their provider can track their blood sugar levels in a few different ways. These include:
<p><b>Blood sugar tests</b>. These tests: Blood sugar tests. These tests measure your blood sugar by taking a small blood sample from your finger with a tiny needle. Typically, they are done throughout the day and before meal times. A doctor can order these, or you can do them at home with a glucometer.
<p><b>A1C tests</b>. These are blood tes: A1C tests. These are blood tests that measure an average of your blood sugar levels over the last three months. This test is done at a lab.
<p>If you have type 1 diabetes, you migh:
If you have type 1 diabetes, you might check blood sugar with a continuous glucose monitor, or CGM. These track sugar levels by using a tiny sensor inserted under the skin. You can then check the reading on a monitor.

CGMs are usually connected to a pump that delivers insulin and corrects blood sugar levels if they’re out of range. You can also check glucose levels and give yourself insulin without a CGM.

<p>Blood sugar is measured in milligrams: Blood sugar is measured in milligrams of sugar per deciliter, or mg/dL. Healthy levels look different for everyone, but generally you should aim for:
<p>Between 70 mg/dL and 130 mg/dL when t: Between 70 mg/dL and 130 mg/dL when testing before mealtimes
<p>Less than 180 mg/dL two hours after m: Less than 180 mg/dL two hours after mealtimes
<p>A1C tests (also referred to as A1C he:
A1C tests (also referred to as A1C hemoglobin tests, or HbA1c tests) measure the average amount of sugar in your blood throughout the past 90 days. The higher the number, the more sugar in your blood.

Generally, an A1C level of 5.7% or lower is healthy. Readings between 5.7% and 6.4% could mean you have pre-diabetes, and readings more than 6.5% mean diabetes.

Depending on your lifestyle or other factors, your healthy A1C range might be different. Ask your doctor what a healthy range is for you.
<h2>Why monitoring your blood sugar is i:
Why monitoring your blood sugar is important

Measuring your blood sugar levels is how you and your care team can determine how you’re managing your diabetes.
<p>Using a glucometer tracks how your bo: Using a glucometer tracks how your body controls your blood sugar on a short-term basis—hour-to-hour, daily, or weekly.
<p>Taking an A1C test determines how you: Taking an A1C test determines how you’re managing your blood sugar throughout a period of three months.
<p>Both can help you and your doctor fig:
Both can help you and your doctor figure out how well you’re meeting your goals. A reading that’s too high or too low can help you determine if you need to reach out for emergency help.

Remember: Your provider will recommend different ways to monitor your blood sugar based on your health history. Talk to your provider about what’s best for you.

<h2>Monitoring With Blood Tests</h2><p>W:
Monitoring With Blood Tests

When it comes to diabetes, tracking your blood sugar (also known as glucose) on a regular basis is one of the most important things you can do.

You or your provider can track your blood sugar in a few different ways. These include:
<p><b>Blood sugar tests</b>. These tests: Blood sugar tests. These tests measure your blood sugar by taking a small blood sample from your finger with a tiny needle. These tests can be done throughout the day and before mealtimes. A doctor can order them, or you can do them at home with a glucometer.
<p><b>A1C tests</b>. These are blood tes: A1C tests. These are blood tests that measure an average of your blood sugar levels during the last three months. This test is done at a lab.
<p>If you have type 1 diabetes, you will: If you have type 1 diabetes, you will likely check your glucose levels with something called a continuous glucose monitor, or CGM. CGMs can also be helpful if you have type 2 diabetes, especially if you use insulin.

<p>Let’s look into how you can do a bloo:
Let’s look into how you can do a blood sugar test.

First, use a very small needle to draw a drop of blood from your finger. Then, you put the blood into a test strip and insert it into a glucometer, which gives a reading.

If you use a CGM, you can check your monitor throughout the day and give yourself insulin based on the reading.

Blood sugar values are measured in milligrams per deciliter, or mg/dL. While you and your healthcare team will decide what a healthy glucose level looks like for you, generally you should aim for:
<p>Between 70 mg/dL and 130 mg/dL first: Between 70 mg/dL and 130 mg/dL first thing in the morning or before mealtimes
<p>A1C tests measure the average amount:
A1C tests measure the average amount of sugar in your blood during a period of 90 days. The higher the number, the more sugar in your blood.

Generally, an A1C level of 5.7% or lower is healthy. Readings between 5.7% and 6.4% could mean you have pre-diabetes, and readings more than r 6.5% mean diabetes.

Depending on your lifestyle or other factors, your healthy A1C range might be different. Ask your doctor what a healthy range is for you.
<p><b>Why monitoring glucose is importan:
Why monitoring glucose is important 

Measuring the amount of glucose in your bloodstream is how you and your care team can determine whether your diabetes is being well controlled—which helps reduce the risk of complications in the short and long term.
<p>Measuring your glucose with a glucose: Measuring your glucose with a glucose meter can help track how your body controls your blood sugar on a short-term basis—hour-to-hour, daily or weekly.
<p>Measuring glucose with an A1C test ca: Measuring glucose with an A1C test can help determine how well your glucose is being controlled during a period of three months.
<p>Either measurement can help you and y: Either measurement can help you and your provider determine whether you’re making progress with your goals, or whether you may need additional interventions, such as oral medication, to keep your blood sugar at a healthy level.
<p><b>Remember</b>: Your provider will r: Remember: Your provider will recommend different ways and times to monitor your blood sugar based on your personal health history. Talk to your provider about what works best for you.

Measure and Record Your Blood Pressure: Measure and Record Your Blood Pressure
<h2>Measure and Record Your Blood Pressu:
Measure and Record Your Blood Pressure

Welcome to the Managing High Blood Pressure program! In this program, you’ll learn about what high blood pressure (BP) - or hypertension is, and how you can change your daily habits to better control it!

BP measures the pressure of blood pushing against the walls of your blood vessels. A blood pressure reading has two numbers:
<p>The top number is your <b>systolic bl: The top number is your systolic blood pressure, which is the pressure in your arteries when your heart beats.
<p>The bottom number is your <b>diastoli: The bottom number is your diastolic blood pressure, which is the pressure in your arteries when your heart rests between beats.
<h3><b>What’s a normal blood pressure re:
What’s a normal blood pressure reading?

Every person is unique, but for most healthy adults, the top number should be less than 120 (but no lower than 90) and the bottom number should be less than 80 (but no lower than 60).

What’s a high blood pressure reading?

The American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association define high blood pressure (also called hypertension) as readings that are consistently above 130/80.

Most people don’t experience any symptoms from high blood pressure, so it’s hard to know if something’s off. That’s where monitoring comes in. If you’ve been diagnosed with hypertension, it's important to check your blood pressure regularly and keep an ongoing record to discuss with your healthcare provider.

In this program you’ll learn steps you can take to better manage high blood pressure.

<h2>Check Your Sodium Intake</h2><p>Sodi:
Check Your Sodium Intake

Sodium (or salt) helps your body maintain normal nerve and muscle function, as well as fluid balance. However, regularly consuming too much salt can contribute to higher blood pressure.  Sodium can be found in many foods, and may be especially high in ones that are prepackaged or processed. Examples include:
<h2>What’s <i>too</i> much salt?</h2><p>:
What’s too much salt?

The daily recommended amount of salt is about one teaspoon or no more than 2300mg per day— in fact the American Heart Association recommends aiming for a limit of 1,500mg per day for most adults, considering that many of us consume sodium unaccounted for within our daily nutrition. 

Next time you prepare a meal, check out the nutrition labels on your food and try to limit each meal to only 600mg of sodium. And when you’re at the grocery store, compare nutrition labels to choose foods with low amounts of salt.
<h3>What are some lower sodium choices?<:
What are some lower sodium choices?

Eat more:
<p>Fruits (fresh, frozen, or canned with: Fruits (fresh, frozen, or canned without added salt)
<p>Vegetables (fresh, frozen or canned,: Vegetables (fresh, frozen or canned, without added salt)
<h3>What are some higher sodium choices?:
What are some higher sodium choices?

Eat less:
<p>Set 1 goal for reducing your sodium t:
Set 1 goal for reducing your sodium that you would like to try in the next few days. 

Some simple changes may be:
<p>Choosing fresh or home-cooked food in: Choosing fresh or home-cooked food instead of fast food (and minimizing added salt when cooking at home)
<p>Selecting fresh fruits and veggies in: Selecting fresh fruits and veggies instead of processed snacks like chips and crackers
<p>Instead of salting your food, add fla: Instead of salting your food, add flavor with lemon, herbs, or other spice

<h2>Learn What Causes High Blood Pressur:
Learn What Causes High Blood Pressure

Several factors can increase the risk of developing high blood pressure. Some risk factors we can't control, like age, family history and genetics. Other risk factors include:
<p>Other health conditions such as obstr: Other health conditions such as obstructive sleep apnea, high cholesterol, and diabetes. Work with your healthcare provider to monitor your risk and make a treatment plan to safely manage these health conditions.
<p>Understanding what might affect your: Understanding what might affect your blood pressure will help you make plans to manage your situation effectively. Luckily, there are things we can do in our day-to-day life to help reduce high blood pressure.
<p>Today, take some time to do a bit of: Today, take some time to do a bit of research and self-reflection. Think about your habits and see if there are any that may be affecting your blood pressure.

<h2>Understand Why Blood Pressure Matter:
Understand Why Blood Pressure Matters

Blood pressure can affect your body in many ways. When left untreated, high blood pressure increases strain on your heart and arteries, which can eventually lead to issues such as:
<p>Blood vessel damage (medically referr: Blood vessel damage (medically referred to as atherosclerosis)
<p>Make an appointment with your doctor: Make an appointment with your doctor or healthcare provider to talk about managing high blood pressure. They can help you come up with a plan that's right for you.
