<h2>Check Your Blood Pressure Accurately:
Check Your Blood Pressure Accurately

Monitoring your blood pressure regularly and accurately is key to managing it effectively. Sometimes it's helpful to check multiple times a day until it's regularly within a healthy range. Everyone’s situation is unique, so ask your doctor how often you should check your blood pressure.
<h2>What causes blood pressure to rise?<:
What causes blood pressure to rise?

Several things can increase blood pressure, so it's best to take a couple of readings at a time to make sure your measurement is accurate.

Keep a log of your readings to share with your doctor. These trends help your healthcare team decide if you need to update your treatment plan (for example, exercising more, eating less salt, or tweaking your medications).

To get accurate blood pressure measurements, avoid these things for at least 30 minutes before taking a reading:
<h2>When to talk to your doctor</h2><h3>:
When to talk to your doctor

If you notice any unusually high or low readings, get in touch with your doctor to book an assessment.
<p>Take a moment to reflect on your rece: Take a moment to reflect on your recent readings that appear higher or lower than normal.
<p>American College of Cardiology. (2017: American College of Cardiology. (2017). How to Take Your Blood Pressure At Home. CardioSmart. Retrieved July 30, 2025.
<h2>Cut Back On Alcohol</h2><p>Drinking:
Cut Back On Alcohol

Drinking alcohol can influence your blood pressure almost immediately. Consuming more than 3 drinks in a single sitting can raise blood pressure for several hours, due to how our bodies process the alcohol. Drinking regularly over the long term can cause chronic high blood pressure. 

Drinking less alcohol can help lower blood pressure and prevent other health issues. In the short term, aim to have no more than 2 alcoholic drinks per day. And in the long term? The less alcohol the better!
<h2>So what next?</h2><p>Swap out an eve:
So what next?

Swap out an evening glass of wine, cocktail, or beer for a healthy alternative such as flavored water or herbal tea.

If you're having trouble cutting back on alcohol, reach out to your doctor for recommendations and support.
<p>Before making big changes to how much: Before making big changes to how much you drink, discuss your plans with your doctor. Suddenly reducing or stopping alcohol consumption can be dangerous and potentially life-threatening if it's not done under the guidance of a medical professional.
<p>For more individualized recommendatio:
For more individualized recommendations and support on cutting back on substance use, contact your healthcare provider.

Before making big changes to your substance use patterns, always discuss your plans with a healthcare provider. Suddenly stopping or reducing use of certain substances can be dangerous and potentially life-threatening if not done under the guidance of a medical professional.

<h2>ACR and eGFR Tests</h2><p>High blood:
ACR and eGFR Tests

High blood sugar can harm your kidneys over time.

Kidney function tests help track how well your kidneys are working. They can be ordered by your provider or someone else on your diabetes care team.

Between 10 and 40 percent of people with type 2 diabetes will develop kidney disease. Screenings can help you and your provider make medication or lifestyle changes to keep your kidneys healthy.
<p><b>An ACR test. </b>If you have prote: An ACR test. If you have protein in your urine, it could mean you have kidney disease. These tests measure the amount of protein in your urine through a urine sample. Medical professionals use ACR tests to find out whether kidney damage or kidney disease is getting worse.
<p><b>My test results aren’t normal. Now:
My test results aren’t normal. Now what? 
First, don’t panic. A low result doesn’t always mean you have chronic kidney disease. Working on keeping your blood sugar within a healthy range can also help slow kidney disease if you do have it. Talk with your provider about next steps to keep your kidneys in tip-top shape.

<h2>Eye Exams</h2><p>Diabetes can often:
Eye Exams

Diabetes can often cause changes in vision, and these can begin well before you even notice them.

So, what’s the solution? First, keeping blood sugar, cholesterol and blood pressure in a normal range. After that, yearly visits to an eye specialist can help you prevent eye damage and find ways to treat your eyes before problems come up.
<p><b>What to expect during your visit</:
What to expect during your visit

During a vision exam, your provider can check for damage by dilating (or widening) your pupils. First, you’ll get some eye drops. Then, the provider will look at your eyes to check for signs of damage. Your provider may use a special camera to take a photo for analysis. Quick and easy.

My provider found some damage. What now?

Damage to your eyes caused by high blood sugar can be permanent. That’s why maintaining healthy blood sugar levels and getting regular eye exams is important. Your provider may ask you to come in for more frequent eye exams. Depending on how it’s progressing, your provider might also recommend other kinds of treatment.

<h2>Monitoring Your Mental Health</h2><p:
Monitoring Your Mental Health

It’s not uncommon to have mental health problems when you’re dealing with a chronic condition. Even if your mental health is in good shape, it’s always a good idea to keep tabs on it.

Your mental health can change as your condition changes. For example, starting insulin or getting diagnosed with another condition (such as high blood pressure) might be hard. For this reason, in addition to your other check-ups, your own mental health should be a priority, too.

Consider reaching out to your provider to see if they can give you a referral to a therapist. They may also be able to suggest a support group for people with diabetes.

<h2>Learn Why Monitoring Is So Important:
Learn Why Monitoring Is So Important

So, you’ve got diabetes. Want to keep track of how well you’re managing it? Good news—you’ve come to the right place!

Whether you have type 1 or type 2 diabetes, monitoring helps keep your blood sugar low. It also reduces your risk of complications.
<h2>What does it mean to “monitor” diabe:
What does it mean to “monitor” diabetes?

Monitoring means making sure your body is functioning the best it can with your diabetes.

In this program, we’ll go over some short- and long-term ways to monitor your diabetes, which include:
<p>But before we get started, take a min: But before we get started, take a minute to tell us more about you.

Based on what you know today, how confid: Based on what you know today, how confident do you feel in your knowledge about the different tests that are essential to support monitoring diabetes?
<h2>Learn About BP Meds</h2><p>Blood pre:
Learn About BP Meds

Blood pressure medications work to keep your blood pressure in a healthy range by relaxing your blood vessels, making your heart beat with less force, or by helping your kidneys regulate the amount of  salt and water in the body.

If your doctor has prescribed medication to control your blood pressure, following their instructions is a key part in safely managing your blood pressure.
<h2>Have questions about your medication:
Have questions about your medications?

If you have any questions about your medication or potential side effects, your pharmacist is an excellent resource. Regular visits with your doctor are also great opportunities to review medications and make adjustments if needed.

Common potential side effects of medications used to treat high BP include:
<p>If you’re experiencing any of these a: If you’re experiencing any of these above symptoms (or other new ones), have a conversation with your doctor so they can make changes to your treatment plan if needed!
Person reading label on medicine bottle: Person reading label on medicine bottle
<h2>Get Moving for 30 Minutes</h2><p>Dai:
Get Moving for 30 Minutes

Daily activity is important to keep your blood pressure in a healthy range.
<p>Get moving in a way that boosts your: Get moving in a way that boosts your heart rate 10 minutes at a time. Try a morning stroll through the neighborhood, dancing to your favorite music, or playing with your kids or pets. Aim for 30 minutes in total.
<h2>Wrap Up and Check In</h2><p>Monitori:
Wrap Up and Check In

Monitoring diabetes can seem like a full-time job, between blood sugar checks and doctor’s visits. Here are a few pointers you can work into a routine.

Keeping up with glucose readings
Check your glucose regularly. Try setting aside however many days your provider recommends as the day (or days) you check your blood sugar. Eventually, it’ll just be one other thing you’re supposed to do on a Sunday, like taking out the trash.
<p><b>Keep your glucometer in plain sigh: Keep your glucometer in plain sight. Have you ever heard the phrase “out of sight, out of mind”? It applies to diabetes, too. Keep your glucometer in an easy-to-access spot like a bathroom counter.
Use your smart device to help. Set an alarm—either for a certain time of day or day of the week—to remind you to use your glucometer.
<p><b>Buddy up</b>. If you have a friend: Buddy up. If you have a friend or family member who’s also trying to keep track of their blood sugar, it may increase your chances of meeting your check-in goals.
<p><b>How to keep track of everything el:
How to keep track of everything else

Monitoring diabetes isn’t just checking your glucose. It’s also about keeping an eye on other potential concerns that might crop up, such as nerve or vision changes.

Along with self-checks, you should regularly schedule visits with a provider to check:
<p>Nerve function in your hands and feet: Nerve function in your hands and feet
<p>If you haven’t had one of these visit: If you haven’t had one of these visits in a year or more, it’s time to schedule an appointment today.
<p>Here’s a quick list on how you can st:
Here’s a quick list on how you can start to build self-checks or periodic tests into your routine:

Schedule an hour.
Set aside some time to make a list of appointments you’ll need to attend throughout the next six months. Once you’ve got your list, sit down and schedule your appointments and write them in your calendar. You’ll be set for the next six months in terms of diabetes care with just an hour’s worth of work.

Make a day of it.
A busy schedule can make it difficult to commit to appointments, even when they’re important. Consider blocking off one full day to take care of all your appointments at once. If your providers are all under the same medical practice or hospital, they may even be able to coordinate your appointments to align during a single day.

Treat yourself (to periodic self-checks).
Admit it: Checking your feet each day is not the most exciting thing ever. Why not treat yourself while you’re at it? Find ways to make it fun instead of just another chore. This will help you look forward to them (and ensure they actually get done).

<h2>Make Balance and Flexibility a Prior:
Make Balance and Flexibility a Priority

Balance and flexibility are important, but they may not always be at the front of mind. Building both skills can improve your health and wellbeing.

Flexibility makes it easier to move your muscles and joints, making it easier to participate in physical activities. Balance can make it easier for you to do things like climb stairs or walk with confidence. Improving both balance and flexibility can decrease your chance of injury and falls, especially if you’re over 65.

As you start this 20-day program, spend some time coming up with a goal for yourself. A good goal might sound like:
<p>“I want to become more flexible so I: “I want to become more flexible so I can feel confident at my sister’s yoga class.”
<p>“I want to work on my balance so I’m: “I want to work on my balance so I’m not worried about falling when out on my own.”

Flex and Balance for Your Best Self: Flex and Balance for Your Best Self
<h2>Flex and Balance for Your Best Self<:
Flex and Balance for Your Best Self

Balance is the way your body learns to stand and move without falling, even if you trip. To balance, lots of your body’s parts and systems need to work together. These include your muscles, your senses, and your nerves.

As you age, it’s harder for your body to balance as well. That can put you at higher risk for a dangerous fall.

Flexibility is what helps your muscles stay loose, so that your joints move more easily.

One way to keep your balance and flexibility skills in tip top shape is with exercise. Staying active, stretching and other activities can help you keep moving and grooving.
<p>Here are a few important tips to keep: Here are a few important tips to keep in mind as you take this program:
<p>Warm up before you stretch. A light w: Warm up before you stretch. A light walk or jog can help you avoid injury when you stretch.
<p>Don’t bounce while you stretch. This: Don’t bounce while you stretch. This can actually injure your muscles.
<p>Keep things even. Try to stretch for: Keep things even. Try to stretch for equal amounts of time on both sides of your body to avoid injury.
<p>Hold your stretch for about 10-30 sec: Hold your stretch for about 10-30 seconds at a minimum. If a particular area of your body feels tight, you can hold for up to 60 seconds too.
<p>Aim for tension, not pain. When a mov: Aim for tension, not pain. When a movement hurts, it means that you’re stretching too far.
<p>Make stretching a practice. Do it reg: Make stretching a practice. Do it regularly to reap the benefits of better flexibility.
<p>If you have health related concerns o: If you have health related concerns or are feeling uncertain about beginning an exercise program, check in with your healthcare provider. They may know of local programs or classes that can help increase safe and effective exercise and stretching.

<h2>Learn About the DASH Diet</h2><p>Die:
Learn About the DASH Diet

Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension, also known as the DASH diet, is a healthy eating plan that helps reduce blood pressure. 

The DASH diet emphasizes foods that are:
<p>Potassium, magnesium, and calcium are: Potassium, magnesium, and calcium are nutrients that help lower blood pressure.
<p>The DASH diet emphasizes <b>vegetable:
The DASH diet emphasizes vegetables, fruits, whole grains, beans, nuts, and low-fat dairy. It also recommends consuming less fatty meat, full-fat dairy, sugary drinks (such as soda or energy drinks), dessert, and salt.

This healthy eating plan not only helps lower your blood pressure over time but also helps lower cholesterol—and decrease your risk of developing type 2 diabetes, too! DASH done well can be healthy and delicious!
<h3><b>Follow these tips to put the DASH: Follow these tips to put the DASH diet into action:
<p>Swap refined grains (like white rice): Swap refined grains (like white rice) for whole grains (like brown rice).
<p>Choose foods with healthier fats (lik: Choose foods with healthier fats (like nuts and olive oil) instead of foods with less-healthy fats (like red meat, fried foods, or full-fat dairy products).
<p>Choose lean protein like fish, poultr: Choose lean protein like fish, poultry, lentils, or beans.
<p>Mayo Clinic. (2021, June 25).<a href=: Mayo Clinic. (2021, June 25). DASH diet: Healthy eating to lower your blood pressure. Retrieved July 30, 2025.
<h2>Build Up Your Activity Level</h2><p>:
Build Up Your Activity Level

Sitting is the new smoking! According to recent studies, too much sitting can be bad for your health—including your blood pressure—even if you exercise regularly. 

Regular (and frequent) physical activity throughout the day strengthens your heart and relaxes your arteries. As your heart gets stronger, it can pump more blood to the rest of your body with less effort, which can help lower your blood pressure and keep your blood vessels in good shape.
<h2>Simple ways to get up and move more: Simple ways to get up and move more often
<p>Schedule an activity break to stretch: Schedule an activity break to stretch and move your body
<p>Walk around or do leg raises during y: Walk around or do leg raises during your next conference call
<p>Keep stretching bands and/or hand wei: Keep stretching bands and/or hand weights near where you watch TV and use them during commercials
<p>Set an alarm at the top of every hour: Set an alarm at the top of every hour and get out of your chair at work and home
<p>Write down ways you could get moving:
Write down ways you could get moving this week. Start by scheduling 10-15 minutes for an activity break. Even small chunks of time can add big impacts on your health.

Say it out loud: "I can do this! I’m committing to moving more!"

<h2>Rest, Relax, and Reflect</h2><p>Both:
Rest, Relax, and Reflect

Both chronic and occasional stress can increase blood pressure.

During a stressful situation, our bodies react by releasing hormones that cause the heart to pump faster and our blood vessels to narrow. This can increase blood pressure in the short term.

However, the effects of long-term stress can produce inflammation in our blood vessels and cause other hormonal changes that contribute to chronically higher blood pressure. While it’s impossible to eliminate all stress, it’s important to reflect on day-to-day stressors and explore ways to manage them.
<p>Today, make time for an activity that: Today, make time for an activity that helps you relax. Maybe that means taking a long walk, reading a book, meditating, or listening to music. Or try this calming meditation video!

<h2>Understand the Link Between BP and W:
Understand the Link Between BP and Weight

Maintaining a healthy weight can help reduce your blood pressure and decrease the stress on your heart and arteries.

Even small changes toward managing your weight can help lower blood pressure. However, instead of focusing on a number on the scale, emphasize a balanced eating plan (remember the DASH diet we talked about?) and add regular physical activity. The combination will help control hypertension and help you maintain a healthy weight.
<p>Take a moment to reflect on the recom: Take a moment to reflect on the recommendations for diet and activity such as moving for 30 minutes or eating more vegetables. Choose 1 thing you can start doing today!
<p>Every person is unique and has a diff: Every person is unique and has a different “ideal” body weight. Speak with your doctor to learn more about what’s a healthy weight

<h2>Preventing Falls</h2><p>By making yo:
Preventing Falls

By making your balance and flexibility exercises a habit, you can really set yourself up to prevent falls. However, it’s worth noting that balance and flexibility can only do so much. While practicing balance and flexibility can help with movement, falls can also be caused by other factors.

There are other factors that can increase someone’s chances of experiencing a fall, including:
<p>Medicines that lead to dizziness or c: Medicines that lead to dizziness or confusion.
<p>Not being able to hold the bladder fo: Not being able to hold the bladder for long, which might make someone rush to the bathroom (i.e., incontinence).
<p>Wearing shoes that don’t provide safe: Wearing shoes that don’t provide safety or support (e.g., high heels).
<p>Safety hazards in your home or enviro: Safety hazards in your home or environment (e.g., a loose rug).
<h2>Reducing Your Risk of Falls</h2><p>A:
Reducing Your Risk of Falls

As you continue on your journey towards better balance and flexibility, think about other ways to lower your fall risk. Talk to your doctor if you are concerned these could put you at risk for falls.

<h2>Keep up the Balance and Flexibility<:
Keep up the Balance and Flexibility

You’ve done so well! Congratulations on working through this program and committing to improving your balance and flexibility. It may not have always been easy, but you kept showing up, and that’s what matters.

Remember: Flexibility and balance go hand in hand. Flexibility helps you become more mobile. By loosening up tighter muscles, it helps support the full range of motion in your joints, improving balance. Balance can help you stay upright and avoid falls.

It’s important to keep up with your balance and flexibility exercises, which you’ve done over the course of this program. Keep up the good work and commit to continuing this practice. Set a goal to continue this practice.

For example: “I will commit to doing step-ups for 5 minutes daily for the next week to improve my balance.”

You may also want to jot down how hard an exercise was on a scale of 1-5 every day to track your progress.
